Key Arguments: The proposed legislation contradicts rights under the Australian Constitution, specifically the right to hold and express opinions.
The government is indirectly empowering Big Tech to censor individuals by threatening them with penalties if they do not control misinformation.
The government has a history of interfering with free speech, as evidenced by past actions of the Department of Home Affairs.
There is concern that critical commentary and dissenting opinions could be labeled as misinformation and censored.
The legislation could potentially impact religious expression and commentary on social issues.
Main Themes: Impact on Religious and Social Commentary
Notable Quotes: By this sleight of hand they can claim that they are not empowering bureaucracy to determine what is true or the power to censor individuals.

I have no confidence in a government which demands the power to deplatform or punish citizens who debate the government-approved opinions.
